title: Quiz 4: The Neuroendocrine System
description: Covers the nervous system (CNS/PNS, brain regions, spinal cord, neurons, neuroglia) and the endocrine system (glands, hormones, hypothalamic control).

questions.question: Which part of the brain is primarily responsible for coordinating smooth, balanced body movements?
questions.explanation: The Cerebellum ('little brain') coordinates posture, balance, and smooth voluntary movements. Lesions here cause ataxia (clumsiness).
questions.hint: Its name means 'little brain' and it's located at the back.

questions.question: Match the cerebral lobe to its primary function/cortex:
questions.explanation: Frontal = Motor/Executive; Parietal = Sensory; Occipital = Vision (eyes in back of head); Temporal = Hearing (near ears).
questions.hint: Temporal is near the temples/ears. Occipital is at the back.

questions.question: Select the components that make up the Brain Stem.
questions.explanation: The Brain Stem consists of the Midbrain, Pons, and Medulla Oblongata. The Cerebellum is attached to it but distinct.
questions.hint: It is the stalk connecting the spinal cord to the forebrain.

questions.question: The ___BLANK___ is the major control center for the internal environment (homeostasis) and regulates the pituitary gland.
questions.explanation: The Hypothalamus controls temperature, hunger, thirst, and the autonomic nervous system, and links to the endocrine system via the pituitary.
questions.hint: It is located 'below' the thalamus.

questions.question: Which neuroglial cells produces the myelin sheath in the Central Nervous System (CNS)?
questions.explanation: Oligodendrocytes myelinate axons in the CNS. Schwann cells myelinate axons in the PNS.
questions.hint: Think 'Oligo-' for CNS, 'Schwann' for PNS.

questions.question: Arrange the meningeal layers from superficial (skull) to deep (brain surface):
questions.explanation: Dura (Tough mother) is outer. Arachnoid (Spider-like) is middle. Pia (Tender mother) is inner, hugging the brain.
questions.hint: D-A-P.

questions.question: The Pineal Gland secretes Melatonin, which regulates circadian rhythms.
questions.explanation: True. The Pineal gland produces melatonin, especially in darkness, to regulate sleep-wake cycles.
questions.hint: It is often called the 'third eye' sensitive to light cycles.

questions.question: Review the diagram description. Where is the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) primarily located?

richContent.content: CSF Circulation: Produced in ventricles, flows through the subarachnoid space, and is reabsorbed into venous blood.

options.text: Between Arachnoid and Pia Mater (Subarachnoid space)

questions.explanation: CSF circulates in the Subarachnoid space (between Arachnoid and Pia) and the ventricles.
questions.hint: Sub- means below the arachnoid layer.

questions.question: Which of the following hormones are produced by the Thyroid Gland?
questions.explanation: The Thyroid produces T3, T4 (metabolism), and Calcitonin (calcium lowering). PTH is from Parathyroids; TSH is from the Pituitary.
questions.hint: TSH stimulates the thyroid but isn't made by it.

questions.question: Match the endocrine gland to its description:

pairs.right: Mixed exo/endocrine gland; Islets of Langerhans
Sits atop kidneys; Cortex and Medulla

questions.explanation: Pancreas has Islets. Adrenals are 'supra-renal' (above kidney). Pituitary is the master gland. Parathyroids are on the posterior thyroid.
questions.hint: Suprarenal means 'above the kidney'.

questions.question: What is the name of the 'Master Gland' attached to the hypothalamus via the infundibulum?
questions.explanation: The Pituitary Gland (Hypophysis) is the master gland controlling many other endocrine organs.
questions.hint: It starts with 'P' and sits in a bony saddle.

questions.question: Which cells in the Testis are responsible for producing Testosterone?
questions.explanation: Interstitial cells of Leydig, found between seminiferous tubules, secrete testosterone. Sertoli cells support sperm.
questions.hint: They are found in the 'interstices' (spaces) between tubules.

questions.question: The dorsal (posterior) root of a spinal nerve carries motor information.
questions.explanation: False. The **Dorsal** root carries **Sensory** (afferent) info. The **Ventral** (anterior) root carries **Motor** (efferent) info.
questions.hint: Remember the mnemonic DAVE: Dorsal Afferent, Ventral Efferent.

questions.question: Identify the functions controlled by the Medulla Oblongata.

options.text: Regulation of heart rate / blood pressure

questions.explanation: The Medulla controls vital life functions: heart rate, BP, breathing, and reflexes like vomiting/swallowing. Reasoning is Cerebrum.
questions.hint: These are 'vital' automatic functions for survival.

questions.question: In the spinal cord, the ___BLANK___ matter is located centrally (H-shape), while the ___BLANK___ matter is on the outside.
questions.explanation: In the spinal cord, Grey matter (cell bodies) is inside. In the brain, Grey matter is mostly outside (cortex).
questions.hint: Opposite of the brain's arrangement.

questions.question: Which cranial nerve is responsible for the sense of smell?
questions.explanation: CN I is the Olfactory nerve (smell). CN II is Optic (sight). CN VIII is Hearing.
questions.hint: It is the first cranial nerve.

questions.question: What is the function of Calcitonin?
questions.explanation: Calcitonin (from thyroid Parafollicular cells) lowers blood calcium by inhibiting osteoclasts. PTH raises it.
questions.hint: It 'tones' down calcium.

questions.question: Which of the following are differences between the Sympathetic and Parasympathetic nervous systems?

options.text: Sympathetic is 'Fight or Flight'; Parasympathetic is 'Rest and Digest'
Sympathetic increases heart rate; Parasympathetic decreases it
Sympathetic originates from Craniosacral; Parasympathetic from Thoracolumbar
Parasympathetic stimulates digestion; Sympathetic inhibits it

questions.explanation: Sympathetic (Thoracolumbar) mobilizes energy (Fight/Flight). Parasympathetic (Craniosacral) conserves energy (Rest/Digest).
questions.hint: Think of what happens when you are scared vs. when you are eating.

questions.question: Order the general path of a reflex arc:
questions.explanation: Stimulus -> Receptor -> Sensory Neuron -> CNS -> Motor Neuron -> Effector -> Response.
questions.hint: Input -> Processing -> Output.

questions.question: The 'Sensory Homunculus' maps body sensations to which specific gyrus of the brain?
questions.explanation: The Postcentral Gyrus is the Primary Somatosensory Cortex. The Precentral Gyrus is the Motor Cortex.
questions.hint: 'Post-' means after; it is behind the central sulcus.
